channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Iran's supreme leader threatens Israel, U.S. with 'crushing response' to Israeli attack
item.description: Iran's supreme leader threatened Israel and the U.S. with “a crushing response” over attacks on Iran and its allies. The Pentagon said Friday that more U.S. forces would be coming to the region.
item.content:encoded:
Iran's supreme leader threatened Israel and the U.S. with “a crushing response” over attacks on Iran and its allies. The Pentagon said Friday that more U.S. forces would be coming to the region.

(Image credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Sikhs march across California urging protections against threats from India on U.S. soil
item.description: Sikh activists marched 350 miles across California in October, marking the 40th anniversary of a massacre and calling for protection from what they say is a growing threat — transnational repression from the Indian government.
item.content:encoded:
Sikh activists marched 350 miles across California in October, marking the 40th anniversary of a massacre and calling for protection from what they say is a growing threat — transnational repression from the Indian government.

(Image credit: Mike Kai Chen for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Sandhya Dirks

item.title: At a historic cemetery in the South, a Dia de los Muertos festival takes root
item.description: At a historic Southern cemetery, a Mexican tradition has found a home.
item.content:encoded:
At a historic Southern cemetery, a Mexican tradition has found a home.

(Image credit: Aaron Sanchez-Guerra)
item.dc:creator: Aaron Sanchez-Guerra

item.title: Opinion: Don't get 'river-crabbed!' How China is cracking down on punny dissent
item.description: China's government is censoring puns and wordplay on-line. NPR's Scott Simon explains why double meanings are a problem for Beijing.
item.content:encoded:
China's government is censoring puns and wordplay on-line. NPR's Scott Simon explains why double meanings are a problem for Beijing.

(Image credit: Andy Wong)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: As ACA sign ups start, more Americans have health insurance than ever. Will it last?
item.description: Enrollment in Affordable Care Act health plans has grown every year of the Biden administration, leading to record low numbers of people who are uninsured.
item.content:encoded:
Enrollment in Affordable Care Act health plans has grown every year of the Biden administration, leading to record low numbers of people who are uninsured.

(Image credit: Jim Vallee/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Selena Simmons-Duffin

item.title: Women sharing personal stories about abortion bans have become a political force
item.description: Women who have suffered unnecessarily after being denied abortions are talking about it publicly, and to support candidates. Could these stories have a political impact in the upcoming election?
item.content:encoded: Women who have suffered unnecessarily after being denied abortions are talking about it publicly, and to support candidates. Could these stories have a political impact in the upcoming election?
item.dc:creator: Rosemary Westwood

item.title: Susan B. Anthony broke the law by voting in 1872. In 2024, women honor her courage
item.description: More than 150 years after Susan B. Anthony was arrested for voting despite being a woman, Americans take to the polls on the anniversary of her historic ballot casting.
item.content:encoded:
More than 150 years after Susan B. Anthony was arrested for voting despite being a woman, Americans take to the polls on the anniversary of her historic ballot casting.

(Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: We talked politics at the North Carolina state fair — and learned 3 key things
item.description: As election day nears, the races loom large over the state fair in North Carolina, where voters are expressing both apathy and anxiety over their top issues and the candidates.
item.content:encoded:
As election day nears, the races loom large over the state fair in North Carolina, where voters are expressing both apathy and anxiety over their top issues and the candidates.

(Image credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: The election in Georgia is tight. Meet 5 groups of voters who will shape the outcome
item.description: In a state decided recently by tiny margins, subtle shifts among any demographic can matter. These five groups could be key in determining who wins Georgia — and possibly the presidency.
item.content:encoded:
In a state decided recently by tiny margins, subtle shifts among any demographic can matter. These five groups could be key in determining who wins Georgia — and possibly the presidency.

(Image credit: Matthew Pearson)
item.dc:creator: Sam Gringlas

item.title: On Arizona's campaign trail, there are 22 tribal lands. He set out to visit them all
item.description: Democrat Ruben Gallego says his party has often taken Native American voters for granted. As he competes for an open Senate seat, he has vowed to visit all of Arizona’s federally-recognized tribes.
item.content:encoded:
Democrat Ruben Gallego says his party has often taken Native American voters for granted. As he competes for an open Senate seat, he has vowed to visit all of Arizona’s federally-recognized tribes.

(Image credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ben Giles
